awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: DINAA (Digital Index of North American Archaeology): Facilitating Big Picture Research in American Archaeology
awd_abstract_narration:
Millions of archaeological sites have been recorded across the United States over the past century. However, this vast record of archaeological data currently remains fragmented in a variety of incompatible formats and database structures scattered across largely inaccessible public and private data stores. The DINAA (Digital Index of North American Archaeology) project will obtain, index, and integrate nonsensitive aspects of this record in coordination with state, tribal, and federal personnel from across the country. The effort is led by  David G. Anderson of the University of Tennessee, Eric C. Kansa of Open Context, Dr. Sarah Whitcher Kansa of the Alexandria Archive Institute, and Dr. Joshua Wells of Indiana University South Bend. The resulting databases and maps have a low spatial resolution to protect site integrity, but will otherwise permit, for the first time, the visualization and exploration of human responses to change in the natural and social environment at a continental scale over the entire period of human settlement in North America. By removing access, legal and technical barriers, this project will offer researchers, land managers, and the public truly "Open Data" to facilitate interdisciplinary research, powerful new approaches to computational modeling, data intensive instruction, and archaeological resource management at local, regional and national scales. The ready availability of online maps, datasets, and links to an ecosystem of similar products and analysis tools will enhance public awareness, use, and appreciation for scientific research in general and archaeology in particular. 

The DINAA project addresses head-on a major challenge facing archaeological informatics: how to connect currently incompatible and fragmentary legacy information systems together so our community can engage in cutting-edge science. The DINAA team has already processed information on over 500,000 sites in 15 states, and this project will expand this effort to the remaining states in North America. DINAA will greatly improve the scientific research value and land management potential of the US archaeological site, report, collections, and other datasets, by broadly employing shared and open data formats, analyses, and dissemination procedures. Anyone using it can download maps, citation records, and other information from the combined site records (no coordinates or other sensitive data are present online) free of charge, and free of intellectual property restrictions. DINAA does this while maintaining strict security. Site locational data is not published or stored; instead, software allocates them to a 400 square kilometer grid (20km on a side) for online visualization. The demonstration that primary archaeological data can be integrated and used to address fundamental questions of human settlement at vast and varying scales will stimulate similar efforts worldwide, and serve as a catalyst to strengthen professional commitments to digital data collection, management, and publication throughout American archaeology, as well as foster public support for scientific research.

por.por_cntn:
The Digital Index of North American Archaeology (DINAA) provides a detailed, current, and growing perspective on past human cultures and their use of the landscapes of the continental United States. DINAA is a data gazetteer based on definitions of archaeological sites recorded in administrative and research databases, including their culture history components and behavioral use types, artifactual and feature evidence, relative and absolute dating information, preservation qualities, and investigative strategies. DINAA is constructed as an exercise in ?linked open data,? which means that it can incorporate hyperlinked references to other archaeological datasets or information resources (e.g., reports, publications, museum collections) as it grows and matures, and provide a mechanism for information discovery through queries on any attribute contained within DINAA.

 

Much of the base data for DINAA are supplied by government offices in the United States, compiled under their obligations related to the National Historic Preservation Act and associated federal and state statutes. These disconnected governmental datasets comprise the most complete public catalog of archaeological sites for the United States. Other datasets come from a variety of museums, curational repositories, and digital publication archives for research (JSTOR) and government (Federal Register). The first phase of DINAA (2012-2016) indexed nearly 300,000 site records in eight US states. The second phase of DINAA (2016-2021) indexed almost one million site records across 39 US states. During the second phase, the project was endorsed by leaders from the Society for American Archaeology, the Society for Historical Archaeology, and the Archaeology Division of the American Anthropological Association. 

 

The DINAA project bridges archaeological theory (how anthropological concepts are communicated through databases), archaeological practice (how information about archaeological investigations are instantiated in databases), archaeological epistemology (what aspects of known data elements are communicated in a database, and why), and archaeological ontology (what are the conceptual and vocabulary structures used to populate a database with meaning). The DINAA dataset of original information, as well as the structure/enabling software of the DINAA database itself are all freely available, open source, citable, published data products. DINAA security protocols ensure no precise site locations or other sensitive information that could endanger heritage resources are ever included in the system.

 

Another aspect of DINAA, the Linking Sites and Literature Project, provides a means by which any published or online resource containing archaeological site numbers can be indexed. Employing full bibliographic citations and stable URLs, this information can be examined spatially by geographic region, and by any of the archaeological concepts of culture, time, and investigation represented in the DINAA site dataset.

DINAA has demonstrated that a national comprehensive archaeological data network is feasible and sustainable with current infrastructural and desktop computing resources. Funding will be required to support construction and maintenance of such a platform, but since information can be user generated, costs are unlikely to be high. DINAA encompasses roughly one third of the known archaeological resources in the continental United States, developed at a cost of ca. $50,000/year over the decade the project has existed. However, greater scientific and political support for such an enterprise is needed. Site counts are low and coverage uneven in many areas because government officials declined to make information available, despite repeated requests, numerous demonstrations of the project?s utility and security, and public statements of support from major professional organizations. Ethics and willpower need to be developed if we are to create the kind of networked and interoperable archaeological datasets needed for large scale research, public education, and resource management purposes. Since much site information is publicly available in a range of sources (e.g. research journals, the Federal Register, individual databases), we developed text mining approaches to finding and indexing large numbers of sites, but with greater effort and less detail than if primary information was shared. 

We are optimistic that a platform like DINAA will become a national standard, given the challenges facing our country to preserve heritage resources in the face of unparalleled threats, and the need to approach solutions collectively. International coordination will quickly follow. We are confident such platforms will of necessity be similar to DINAA, as recognition of its utility and comprehensiveness grows, and as efforts to develop informatics competency and resources expand. DINAA is recognized domestically and internationally as an easily adopted solution to the challenge of coordinating and querying archaeological information. NSF funding has been critical for generating support for DINAA, but it must also be acknowledged that most data was supplied voluntarily. We believe for a truly national heritage database to be developed, its creation must reflect an ethos of openness supported and indeed mandated by research and development agencies, and tied to funding supporting the creation and use of archaeological information.

We invite you to explore the archaeological record with DINAA - http://ux.opencontext.org/archaeology-site-data
